statement:
Let $p\geq 5$ be a prime and let $G={\operatorname{SL}}(2,\mathbb{F}_p)$
be the special linear group over the field with $p$ elements.

The group $G={\operatorname{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{F}_p})$ has no non-trivial
$1$ dimensional irreducible representations over ${\mathbb{F}_p}$.

See an for the proof.

Next, we construct several irreducible representations for
$G={\operatorname{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{F}_p})$. For $0\leq m \leq p-1$, let
$V_m$ be the ${\mathbb{F}_p}$ vector space of homogeneous polynomials of
degree $m$ in the independent variables $x$ and $y$ (of course, for
$m=0$, the representation is trivial). We give $V_m$ a structure of
${\mathbb{F}_p}[G]$-module as follows. Let $p=p((x,y))\in V_m$ and
$A\in {\operatorname{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{F}_p})$. We define:
$$A\cdot p := p( A\cdot (x,y)^t)=p(a_{11}x+a_{12}y,a_{21}x+a_{22}y)$$
where $t$ denotes transpose. The representations $V_m$ are, in a sense,
all the irreducible representations of $G$.

For $0\leq m \leq p-1$, the representations $V_m$ are irreducible
representations of dimension $m+1$ over ${\mathbb{F}_p}$. Furthermore,
up to isomorphism, there are no other irreducible representations of $G$
over ${\mathbb{F}_p}$.

[00]{} Charles B. Thomas, [*Representations of Finite and Lie
Groups*]{}, Imperial College Press, London.
names: irreducible representations of the special linear group over $\mathbb{F}_p$
